caption_original:
Quiz time for kids: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called?
- Carbon footprint
- Carbon sinks
- Carbon magic

Encourage your children and students to learn about climate science by playing the Climate Science Brain Buster Quiz on the Climate Kids website.
https://climatekids.ca/ 

 
ANSWER:
Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called carbon sinks.
Carbon sinks such as oceans, forests and wetlands remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by absorbing it like a sponge. We can help reduce effects of climate change by protecting natural ecosystems that are carbon sinks.

ANSWER: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called carbon sinks. Carbon sinks such as oceans, forests and wetlands remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by absorbing it like a sponge. We can help reduce effects of climate change by protecting natural ecosystems that are carbon sinks.

caption_original:
Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). 

We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. 

Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.
caption_cleaned: Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

caption_original: Last week in Montreal, Canada was proud to host 195 countries for the annual Montreal Protocol meeting. Working together under this global agreement, we can tackle climate change and build a healthy, sustainable future for our kids and grandkids.

caption_original:
Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. 

At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the 2017 UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. 

SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted. http://ow.ly/sD6G30gAhTI
caption_cleaned: Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted.

Households use chemical pesticides and fertilizers to get rid of unwanted plants, insects and to keep up the appearance of lawns and gardens. But these chemicals can have negative environmental and health effects; they can pollute lakes and rivers and can be harmful to many forms of life including species that help the environment. 

Although Canadian households have been using less chemical pesticides and fertilizers since 1994, this use has increased in recent years. Check out Environment and Climate Change Canada's Canadian Environmental Indicators for the latest results:
http://ow.ly/INdg30gJjXb #CdnEnv #Sustainability #Indicators
